title: What is the best blues harmonica to buy? - Quora

response.answer_text: Q: What is the best blues harmonica to buy? There are many possibilities since “the best blues harmonica” really is a matter of personal preference. For every one of the most popular models from each of the major manufacturers there are outstanding players who find that particular model their favourite. While many prefer production models, some of the best players prefer instruments from the major manufacturers that have been customised by one or other of the top harmonica customisers. Still others prefer instruments from the smaller manufacturers such as Dortel and Yonberg. Of the standard models from the main manufacturers, here are some of the most popular models among our professional customers. From Hohner: 580/20 Meisterklasse MS[1], 2009/20 Marine Band Crossover[2], 2013/20 Rocket[3], 2005/20 Marine Band Deluxe[4], 1896/20 Marine Band Classic[5], 560/20 Special 20[6]. From Seydel: 16501 1847 Noble[7], 16201 1847 Classic[8], 16301 1847 Silver[9], 10301 Session Steel[10]. From Suzuki: M-20 Manji[11], MR-350 Promaster[12], MR-500 Firebreath[13]. From Lee Oskar: 1910 Major Diatonic[14].  If you're interested in harmonicas, please also see my harmonica blog here: HarpQuora. Footnotes[1] Meisterklasse[2] Marine Band Crossover[3] Rocket[4] Marine Band Deluxe[5] Marine Band 1896[6] Special 20[7] 1847 NOBLE - C.A. SEYDEL SÖHNE[8] 1847 CLASSIC - C.A. SEYDEL SÖHNE[9] 1847 SILVER - C.A. SEYDEL SÖHNE[10] SESSION STEEL - C.A. SEYDEL SÖHNE[11] Suzuki World Class Harmonicas[12] Suzuki World Class Harmonicas[13] MandoHarp - Diatonic Harmonica[14] Major Diatonic Harmonica

There is no best to buy, there is just what you’d like when it comes to sound and experience. I started out with Hohner Bluesharps / Marina Bands, but my kit now is entirely made out of Lee Oskars. The Hohners have wood combs, the Lee’s have “plastic” ones. This changes the tone, where woods makes the feel a bit warmer.Also keep in mind that these are Diatonic harmonica’s in a Major tuning, which is perfect for the blues scale. Where as chromatic ones (normal music scale) are harder to learn to play. If you are starting out, go for the Hohners they are very forgiving harps.
